awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Applicability limits of aqueous pKa values for bulk and surface nanoparticle processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Chemistry Division's Environmental Chemical Sciences Program. The collaborative study involves Professors Kelley Barsanti and Bryan Wong at the University of California, Riverside, and Prof. James Smith at the University of California, Irvine. Together with their graduate and undergraduate students, they investigate the acidity of atmospheric aerosols (very fine droplets in the atmosphere). Several key processes that cause small particles to form and grow in the atmosphere are controlled by the acidity of the surface and interior of aerosol particles. The formation and growth of these small particles in the atmosphere have implications for their effects on health as well as their potential to directly and indirectly impact climate. Atmospheric aerosols are particles that are often smaller than 100 nanometers in diameter. Typical descriptions of acidity fail to adequately represent the acid-base chemistry in these particles because they are so small.  This project seeks to understand the limits of the applicability of an acidity measurements (here, acid dissociation constants (pKa)) in describing the behavior of acids and bases in sub-100 nanometer particles. As part of a long-standing summer internship program for undergraduates, the researchers give real-time demonstrations using the AVOGADRO program, which provides an easy-to-use graphical user-interface to create acid-base molecular systems and perform preliminary, low-level simulations relevant to this project. As such, the project provides real-time demonstrations may have a substantial impact in increasing awareness of computationally-guided experiments in underrepresented minority populations, potentially leading to more minority students seeking careers in the environmental chemical sciences.

The goal of this research is to determine the limits of applicability for bulk-phase aqueous acid and base dissociation constants (pKa and pKb), particularly as regards acid-base chemistry in and on sub-100 nm particles. In this size range, the direct composition and indirect hygroscopicity measurements performed at the CLOUD chamber show that nanoparticles formed by sulfuric acid in the presence of excess based(amines and ammonia) are more acidic than predicted using thermodynamic models.  Further, the acidity appears to vary with particle size from ~10 nm (most acidic) to 50 nm (more neutralized). Knowledge of the acidity of sub-100 nm particles is important for understanding relatively simple acid-base chemistry, but also for accurately predicting acid-catalyzed processes on particle surfaces and in the bulk phase.  The specific objectives of this project are as follows: to use molecular modeling to predict pKa values for inorganic and organic acids and bases as a function of particle composition and size. This activity combines techniques such a computational quantum chemistry and molecular dynamics to model particles with diameters of up to 5 nm and to perform laboratory experiments to evaluate the predicted pKa values as a function of composition and size. This is done using a temperature- and humidity-controlled reaction chamber and chemical ionization mass spectrometers to determine precursor and nanoparticle composition.  The researchers will also develop and apply a parameterization applicable for multiscale modeling of relevant processes taking place in and on atmospheric aerosol particles. This latter research aim may lead to improvements in the predictive power of models. These models address the mechanisms and species responsible for the formation of new particles in the atmosphere, and the effects of atmospheric nanoparticles on human health and climate.

por.por_cntn:
New particle formation is the spontaneous creation of new nanometer-sized particles in the atmosphere. Observations spanning from megacities to isolated forests show that these events can occur frequently and extend for hundreds of square kilometers. While the impacts of these events are not well understood, they are often the dominant source of particles in the remote regions and could play a crucial role in the Earth's climate by regulating the number and activity of cloud condensation nuclei. Since cloud droplet activation normally occurs on particles of about 100 nm in diameter, the key to understanding the impact of new particle formation on climate lies in the ability to predict the initial cluster formation as well as growth rates of these clusters as they grow to climate-relevant sizes. The most important process responsible for atmospheric cluster formation is the reaction between gas phase acids and bases. Once clusters form, other processes such as the uptake of organic vapors may contribute to growth but this is highly dependent on the chemical composition of the nascent cluster. A key chemical property in newly formed clusters and nanoparticles is acidity, which generally refers to the ability of a compound to make new chemical bonds by acting as a proton donor or electron acceptor. This project focuses on how nanoparticles form in the atmosphere from reactions of acids and bases, how the acidity of clusters and nanoparticles change as particles grow, and the role that acidity plays in the chemical processes that determine growth.

In order to study the role of acidity in cluster formation and nanoparticle growth, laboratory experiments were combined with computer simulations that accurately describe proton transfer reactions that occur between acids and bases. The lab experiments provide insights into what actually happens in nanoparticles, whereas the computer simulations allow one to actually understand why. Lab experiments were performed using a unique instrument that can determine the composition of particles with diameters as small as 5 nm. One surprising result from these experiments was that nanoparticle composition from the reactions of acids and bases is highly size-dependent. The smallest particles appear to be more acidic, that is, contain more acid molecules compared to base molecules. As these particles grow, they take up more bases until they become neutral, meaning that for every acid molecule that has lost a proton there is a base molecule that has accepted a proton. This observation that the smallest atmospheric clusters and nanoparticles are likely acidic is not currently adopted in most climate and air quality models and could have important consequences as many growth processes are accelerated under acidic conditions. 

In addition to the targeted studies described above, computer simulations addressed other questions related to nanoparticle formation from reactions of acids with bases. One study explored the synergistic effects of ammonia and amines as they react in clusters with sulfuric acid. That study demonstrated that, at atmospheric conditions, the synergistic effects cause up to five orders of magnitude increase in particle formation rates. This result has implications in the interpretation of field measurement data and the incorporation of particle formation rates into climate models, since the most common assumption is that sulfuric acid reacts individually with either ammonia or amines. Another set of studies used computer simulations to identify potentially important new atmospheric bases. Specifically, trimethylamine oxide and guanidine were identified as being highly effective in created new particles from reactions with a variety of acids. Other theoretical studies explored the role of water vapor in new particle formation as well as the effect of base strength on cluster composition. In total, the modeling studies of the project provided new insights into how particles form from acid-base chemistry and why different chemical systems show different formation rates.

A final study combined all the observations described above to create a model that can be used to predict particle formation rates from acid-base chemistry. The prediction of atmospheric particle formation rates is often a tedious process that requires a large amount of computational resources. To address this, a computational "shortcut" that bypasses the need for expensive computer simulations is presented. This shortcut involves only one calculation: the stability of the first acid-base pair (called heterodimer), which is used to develop a model that predicts particle formation rates at any temperature, pressure, and acid/base concentration. The model agrees well with prior measurements without the need for adjustable parameters.

A number of students and postdoctoral fellows received training in the fundamental chemistry of the atmosphere and the implications for air quality and climate change.  Outreach to UCI undergraduate students who were from under-represented groups in STEM involved developing a series of demonstrations for an introductory chemistry course that served to explain key concepts while also introducing these students to the opportunities for on-campus research during the course of their studies.
